tackle these issues, we introduce TopicGPT, a prompt-based framework that uses large language models (LLMs) to uncover latent topics within a provided text collection. TopicGPT produces topics that align better with human categorizations compared to competing methods: for example, it achieves a harmonic mean purity of 0.74 against human-annotated Wikipedia topics compared to 0.64 for the strongest baseline. Its topics are also more interpretable, dispensing with ambiguous bags of words in favor of topics with natural language labels and associated free-form descriptions. Moreover, the framework is highly adaptable, allowing users to specify constraints and modify topics without the need for model retraining. TopicGPT can be further extended to hierarchical topical modeling, enabling users to explore topics at various levels of granularity. By streamlining access to high-quality and interpretable topics, TopicGPT represents a compelling, human-centered approach to topic modeling.

import requests
import json

def scraper(url:str) -> None:
  # Make a GET request to the provided URL
  response = requests.get(url)

  # Parse the content of the response using Beautiful Soup
  soup = bs4.BeautifulSoup(response.content, 'html.parser')

  paper_title = soup.find('h1', class_='title mathjax').text.replace('Title:','').strip()
  authors = soup.find('div', class_='authors').text.replace('Authors:','').strip()
  abstract = soup.find('blockquote', class_='abstract mathjax').text.replace('Abstract:','').strip()

  data = {
      'paper_title': paper_title,
      'authors': authors,
      'abstract': abstract
  }

  # Convert the dictionary to JSON format and print it out
  print(json.dumps(data, indent=4))
